questions.question: When coupling doubles, which trailer should be positioned first (closest to the tractor)?
questions.explanation: The heavier trailer should be positioned closest to the tractor. This improves stability and handling of the combination.

questions.question: Converter dollies built after March 1, 1998 are required to have:
questions.explanation: Converter dollies built on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have ABS. Look for the yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the left side.

questions.question: On most converter dollies, the ABS warning lamp is located:
choices: On the left side of the dolly
On the rear of the dolly frame
questions.explanation: On converter dollies, the ABS warning lamp is on the left side of the dolly.

questions.question: When inspecting doubles/triples, where should the shut-off valves be positioned?
choices: Closed on all trailers in the set
Open on all trailers in the set
Open on all except the last trailer
Closed on only the first trailer
questions.explanation: Shut-off valves should be open on all trailers except the last one. The valves on the rear of the last trailer should be closed.

questions.question: You should NEVER unlock the pintle hook with the dolly still under a trailer because:
choices: The dolly tow bar may fly up
questions.explanation: Never unlock the pintle hook with the dolly still under a trailer. The dolly tow bar may fly up, potentially causing injury.

questions.question: In a set of doubles or triples, which trailer is most likely to turn over?
questions.explanation: The rearmost trailer is most likely to turn over due to the 'crack-the-whip' effect during sudden steering movements.

questions.question: What is the 'crack-the-whip' effect?
choices: When brakes lock up on slippery roads
When the rear trailer amplifies steering input
When air pressure drops in the system
questions.explanation: The crack-the-whip effect occurs when a sudden steering movement causes the rearmost trailer to swing out much more than the tractor, potentially causing rollover.

questions.question: Compared to single trailers, doubles and triples have:
questions.explanation: Doubles and triples have a higher risk of rollover due to their length, multiple pivot points, and the crack-the-whip effect.

questions.question: When coupling a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer air tanks should be:
questions.explanation: The trailer air tanks should be fully charged before coupling to ensure proper brake operation and easier coupling.

questions.question: When coupling a second trailer, after positioning the converter dolly, what is the next step?
choices: Connect air lines and light cord
Back the converter dolly under the rear trailer
questions.explanation: After positioning the dolly in front of the second trailer, back the converter dolly under the rear trailer. Air lines and light cords are connected after the dolly is coupled.

questions.question: Before disconnecting a converter dolly, you should:
choices: Apply spring brakes on the dolly
questions.explanation: Before disconnecting a converter dolly, apply the spring/parking brakes on the dolly to prevent it from rolling.

questions.question: When driving doubles/triples, you should look how far ahead?
choices: Only as far as the next light
questions.explanation: Look further ahead when driving doubles or triples because it takes longer to stop and you need more time to react.

questions.question: The service line of a converter dolly is typically what color?
questions.explanation: Service lines are typically blue. The emergency/supply line is typically red.

questions.question: When uncoupling the rear trailer in a set of doubles, you should:
choices: Disconnect the air lines and pull away
Lower the landing gear before anything else
Release the parking brakes and pull forward
questions.explanation: Lower the landing gear before disconnecting any lines to support the trailer. This prevents the trailer from dropping.

questions.question: To prevent rollover when driving doubles/triples, you should:
choices: Speed up through curves for stability
Make quick lane changes when needed
Keep cargo low and take curves slowly
Brake hard entering curves to slow down
questions.explanation: Keep cargo low and drive slowly around curves. Avoid quick lane changes and sudden steering movements to prevent the crack-the-whip effect.

questions.question: The safety catch for the pintle hook should be:
questions.explanation: The safety catch for the pintle hook must be closed and latched to prevent accidental uncoupling.

questions.question: When checking the converter dolly air tank drain valve, you should:
questions.explanation: The air tank drain valve should be closed. An open valve would let air escape and could cause brake failure.

questions.question: What should you check on the pintle hook during your pre-trip inspection?
choices: That it is freshly painted and visible
That the latch is secure and hook is intact
That it swivels and moves freely
That it is connected to the dolly frame
questions.explanation: Check that the pintle hook is not cracked or broken, that the safety latch is in place, and that it's properly secured.

questions.question: Following distance for doubles/triples should be:
questions.explanation: Following distance should be greater for doubles/triples because they take longer to stop and require more room for maneuvering.

questions.question: When you make a sharp turn with doubles/triples, what happens to the rear trailer?
choices: It follows the same path as the tractor
It cuts the corner more than the tractor
It swings wider than the tractor does
It straightens out and goes straight
questions.explanation: The rear trailer cuts the corner more sharply (off-tracking). You must make wider turns to compensate for this.
